Dispute_Type: Dispute over shrimp fishing quota allocation based on historical catches
Legal_Issue: Does the Minister of Fisheries and Oceans have the discretion to impose conditions on fishing licenses, specifically quotas?
Governing_Law: Fisheries Act, s. 7; Atlantic Fishery Regulations, s. 33(1)
Evidence_Assessment: The applicant was given a minimum quota due to his inability to fish from 1984-1989; the Department followed a program agreed upon by 87% of fishermen
Legal_Rule: Under s. 7 of the Fisheries Act, the Minister has discretionary power to issue licenses and impose conditions under s. 33(1) of the Atlantic Fishery Regulations
Grounds_for_Claim: Challenge to the Minister’s decision on quota allocation
Outcome_on_Merits: The court found the decision reasonable and within the Minister's discretion
Key_Evidence_Considered: Historical fishing inability (1984–1989); consensus among 87% of fishermen on the program
Applicant_Challenge: Challenging the Minister’s decision on quota allocation
Court_Result: Application dismissed, no order as to costs
Legal_Rule_Source: Fisheries Act, s. 7; Atlantic Fishery Regulations, s. 33(1)
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence, administrative records, historical data
Remedy_Sought: Judicial intervention to overturn quota decision
Legal_Provision: Fisheries Act, s. 7; Atlantic Fishery Regulations, s. 33(1)
Legal_Provision_Cited: Fisheries Act, s. 7; Atlantic Fishery Regulations, s. 33(1)
Grounds_for_Inadmissibility_or_Allegatio: Allegation that quota decision was unreasonable or outside ministerial discretion
Applicable_Process: Administrative decision-making followed by judicial review
